Accelerating Federated Learning via
Momentum Gradient Descent

Wei Liu, Li Chen, Yunfei Chen, and Wenyi Zhang W. Liu, L. Chen and W. Zhang are with Department of Electronic Engineering and Information Science, University of Science and Technology of China. (e-mail: liuwei93@mail.ustc.edu.cn, {chenli87, wenyizha}@ustc.edu.cn). Y. Chen is with the School of Engineering, University of Warwick, Coventry CV4 7AL, U.K. (e-mail: Yunfei.Chen@warwick.ac.uk).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) provides a communication-efficient approach to solve machine learning problems concerning distributed data, without sending raw data to a central server. However, existing works on FL only utilize first-order gradient descent (GD) and do not consider the preceding iterations to gradient update which can potentially accelerate convergence. In this paper, we consider momentum term which relates to the last iteration. The proposed momentum federated learning (MFL) uses momentum gradient descent (MGD) in the local update step of FL system. We establish global convergence properties of MFL and derive an upper bound on MFL convergence rate. Comparing the upper bounds on MFL and FL convergence rate, we provide conditions in which MFL accelerates the convergence. For different machine learning models, the convergence performance of MFL is evaluated based on experiments with MNIST dataset. Simulation results comfirm that MFL is globally convergent and further reveal significant convergence improvement over FL.

Index Terms:
accelerated convergence, distributed machine learning, federated learning, momentum gradient descent.

I Introduction

Recently, data-intensive machine learning has been applied in various fields, such as autonomous driving [1], speech recognition [2], image classification [3] and disease detection [4] since this technique provides beneficial solutions to extract the useful information hidden in data. It now becomes a common tendency that machine-learning systems are deploying in architectures that include ten of thousands of processors [5]. Great amount of data is generated by various parallel and distributed physical objects.

Collecting data from edge devices to the central server is necessary for distributed machine learning scenarios. In the process of distributed data collection, there exist significant challenges such as energy efficiency problems and system latency problems. The energy efficiency of distributed data collection was considered in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) due to limited battery capacity of sensors [6]; In fifth-generation (5G) cellular networks, a round-trip delay from terminals through the network back to terminals demands much lower latencies, potentially down to 1 ms, to facilitate human tactile to visual feedback control [7]. Thus, the challenges of data aggregation in distributed system urgently require communication-efficient solutions.

In order to overcome these challenges, cutting down transmission distance and reducing the amount of uploaded data from edge devices to the network center are two effective ways. To reduce transmission distance, mobile edge computing (MEC) in [8] is an emerging technique where the computation and storage resources are pushed to proximity of edge devices where the local task and data offloaded by users can be processed. In this way, the distance of large-scale data transmission is greatly shortened and the latency has a significant reduction [9]. Using machine learning for the prediction of uploaded task execution time achieves a shorter processing delay [10], and dynamic resource scheduling was studied to optimize resources allocation of MEC system in [11]. Moreover, using machine learning to offload computation for MEC can further reduce the computation and communication overhead [12]. To reduce the uploaded data size, model-based compression approaches, where raw data are compressed and represented by well-established model parameters, demonstrate significant compression performance [13]. Lossy compression is also an effective strategy to decrease the uploaded data size [14], [15]. Compressed sensing, where the sparse data of the edge can be efficiently sampled and reconstructed with transmitting a much smaller data size, was applied to data acquisition of Internet of Things (IoT) network [16], [17]. Further, the work in [18] proposed a blockchain-based data sharing to enhance the communication efficiency across resource-limited edges. All the aforementioned works need to collect raw data from individual device.

To avoid collecting raw data for machine learning in distributed scenarios, a novel approach named Federated Learning (FL) has emerged as a promising solution [19]. The work in [20] provided a fundamental architecture design of FL. Considering the growing computation capability of edge nodes (devices), FL decentralizes the centralized machine learning task and assigns the decomposed computing tasks to the edge nodes where the raw data are stored and learned at the edge nodes. After a fixed iteration interval, each edge node transmits its learned model parameter to the central server. This strategy can substantially decrease consumption of communication resources and improve communication-efficiency. To further improve the energy efficiency of FL, the work in [21] proposed an adaptive FL approach, where the aggregation frequency can be adjusted adaptively to minimize the loss function under a fixed resource budget. To reduce the uplink communication costs, the work in [22] proposed structured and sketched updates method, and compression techniques were adopted to reduce parameter dimension in this work. A novel algorithm was proposed to compress edge node updates in [23]. In this algorithm, gradient selection and adaptive adjustment of learning rate were used for efficient compression. For security aggregation of high-dimensional data, the works in [24], [25] provided a communication-efficient approach, where the server can compute the sum of model parameters from edge nodes without knowing the contribution of each individual node. In [26], under unbalanced resource distribution in network edge, FL with client (edge node) selection was proposed for actively managing the clients aggregation according to their resources condition. In [27], non-iid data distribution was studied and a strategy was proposed to improve FL learning performance under this situation.

However, existing FL solutions generally use gradient descent (GD) for loss function minimization. GD is a one-step method where the next iteration depends only on the current gradient. Convergence rate of GD can be improved by accounting for more preceding iterations [28]. Thus, by introducing the last iteration, which is named momentum term, momentum gradient descent (MGD) can accelerate the convergence. The work in [29] gave a theoretical explanation that under the assumption of strong convexity, MGD speeds up the convergence in comparison with GD. Further work in [30] provided conditions in which MGD is globally convergent.

Motivated by the above observation, we propose a new federated learning design of Momentum Federated Learning (MFL) in this paper. In the proposed MFL design, we introduce momentum term in FL local update and leverage MGD to perform local iterations. Further, the global convergence of the proposed MFL is proven. We derive the theoretical convergence bound of MFL. Compared with FL [21], the proposed MFL has an accelerated convergence rate under certain conditions. On the basis of MNIST dataset, we numerically study the proposed MFL and obtain its loss function curve. The experiment results show that MFL converges faster than FL for different machine learning models. The contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    MFL design: According to the characteristic that MGD facilitates machine learning convergence in the centralized situation, we propose MFL design where MGD is adopted to optimize loss function in local update. The proposed MFL can improve the convergence rate of distributed learning problem significantly.

  • •

    Convergence analysis for MFL: We prove that the proposed MFL is globally convergent on convex optimization problems, and derive its theoretical upper bound on convergence rate. We make a comparative analysis of convergence performance between the proposed MFL and FL. It is proven that MFL improves convergence rate of FL under certain conditions.

  • •

    Evaluation based on MNIST dataset: We evaluate the proposed MFL’s convergence performance via simulation based on MNIST dataset with different machine learning models. Then an experimental comparison is made between FL and the proposed MFL. The simulation results show that MFL is globally convergent and confirm that MFL provides a significant improvement of convergence rate.

The remaining part of this paper is organized as follows. We introduce the system model to solve the learning problem in distributed scenarios in Section II and subsequently elaborate the existing solutions in Section III. In Section IV, we describe the design of MFL in detail. Then in Section V and VI, we present the convergence analysis of MFL and the comparison between FL and MFL, respectively. Finally, we show experimentation results in Section VII and draw a conclusion in Section VIII.

II System Model

In this paper, considering a simplified system model, we discuss the distributed network as shown in Fig. 1. This model has N𝑁N edge nodes and a central server. This N𝑁N edge nodes, which have limited communication and computation resources, contain local datasets 𝒟1,𝒟2,…,𝒟i,…,𝒟Nsubscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2…subscript𝒟𝑖…subscript𝒟𝑁\mathcal{D}_{1},\mathcal{D}_{2},...,\mathcal{D}_{i},...,\mathcal{D}_{N}, respectively. So the global dataset is 𝒟≜𝒟1∪𝒟2∪⋯∪𝒟N≜𝒟subscript𝒟1subscript𝒟2⋯subscript𝒟𝑁\mathcal{D}\triangleq\mathcal{D}_{1}\cup\mathcal{D}_{2}\cup\cdots\cup\mathcal{D}_{N}. Assume that 𝒟i∩𝒟j=∅subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝒟𝑗\mathcal{D}_{i}\cap\mathcal{D}_{j}=\emptyset for i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. We define the number of samples in node i𝑖i as |𝒟i|subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}_{i}| where |⋅||\cdot| denotes the size of the set. The total number of all nodes’ samples is |𝒟|𝒟|\mathcal{D}|, and |𝒟|=∑i=1N|𝒟i|𝒟superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}|=\sum_{i=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|. The central server connects all the edge nodes for information transmission.

We define the global loss function at the central server as F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}), where w denotes the model parameter. Different machine learning models correspond to different F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) and w. We use w∗superscriptw\textbf{w}^{*} to represent the optimal parameter for minimizing the value of F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}). Based on the presented model, the learning problem is to minimize F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}) and it can be formulated as follows:

w∗≜argminF​(w).≜superscriptw𝐹w\displaystyle\textbf{w}^{*}\triangleq\mathop{\arg}\mathop{\min}F(\textbf{w}). (1)

Because of the complexity of machine learning model and original dataset, finding a closed-form solution of the above optimization problem is usually impossible. So algorithms based on gradient iterations are used to solve (1). If raw user data are collected and stored in the central server, we can use centralized learning solutions to (1) while if raw user data are distributed over the edge nodes, FL and the proposed MFL can be applied to optimize this learning problem.

Under the situation where FL or MFL solutions are used, the local loss function of node i𝑖i is denoted by Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textbf{w}) which is defined merely on 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}. Then we define the global loss function F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}) on 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} as follows:

Definition 1 (Global loss function).

Given the loss function Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) of edge node i𝑖i, we define the global loss function on all the distributed datasets as

F​(w)≜∑i=1N|𝒟i|​Fi​(w)|𝒟|.≜𝐹wsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖w𝒟\displaystyle F(\textup{{w}})\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|F_{i}(\textup{{w}})}{|\mathcal{D}|}. (2)

III Existing Solutions

In this section, we introduce two existing solutions to solve the learning problem expressed by (1). These two solutions are centralized learning solution and FL solution, respectively.

III-A Centralized Learning Solution

Centralized machine learning is for machine learning model embedded in the central server and each edge node needs to send its raw data to the central sever. In this situation, edge nodes will consume communication resources for data transmission, but without incurring computation resources consumption.

After the central server has collected all datasets from the edge nodes, a usual way to solve the learning problem expressed by (1) is GD which globally converges for convex optimization problem. However, due to the one-step nature of GD that each update relates only to the current iteration, the convergence performance of GD still has the potential to be improved by accounting for the history of iterations. There exist multi-step methods where the next update relies not only on the current iteration but also on the preceding ones. MGD is the simplest multi-step method to solve the learning problem of (1) with convergence acceleration. In MGD, each gradient update includes the last iteration which is called the momentum term. It has been proven that MGD improves convergence rate of GD in [29].

III-A1 GD

The update rule for GD is as follows:

w​(t)=w​(t−1)−η​∇F​(w​(t−1)).w𝑡w𝑡1𝜂∇𝐹w𝑡1\displaystyle\textbf{w}(t)=\textbf{w}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F(\textbf{w}(t-1)). (3)

In (3), t𝑡t denotes the iteration index and η>0𝜂0\eta>0 is the learning step size. The model parameter w is updated along the direction of negative gradient. Using the above update rule, GD can solve the learning problem with continuous iterations.

III-A2 MGD

As an improvement of GD, MGD introduces the momentum term and we present its update rules as follows:

d​(t)d𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{d}(t) =γ​d​(t−1)+∇F​(w​(t−1))absent𝛾d𝑡1∇𝐹w𝑡1\displaystyle=\gamma\textbf{d}(t-1)+\nabla F(\textbf{w}(t-1)) (4)
w​(t)w𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{w}(t) =w​(t−1)−η​d​(t),absentw𝑡1𝜂d𝑡\displaystyle=\textbf{w}(t-1)-\eta\textbf{d}(t), (5)

where d​(t)d𝑡\textbf{d}(t) is the momentum term which has the same dimension as w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t), γ𝛾\gamma is the momentum attenuation factor, η𝜂\eta is the learning step size and t𝑡t is the iteration index. By iterations of (4) and (5) with t𝑡t, F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}) can potentially converge to the minimum faster compared with GD. The convergence range of MGD is −1<γ<11𝛾1-1<\gamma<1 with a bounded η𝜂\eta and if 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1, MGD has an accelerated convergence rate than GD under a small η𝜂\eta typically used in simulations [31, Result 3].

III-B FL Solution

Collecting and uploading the distributed data are challenging for communication-constrained distributed network. Due to the limited communication resources at edge nodes, the transmission latency of raw user data could be large which deteriorates network feedback performance. Also, the transmission of user data is prone to be at the risk of violating user privacy and security over the entire network. In order to overcome these challenges, FL was proposed as a communication-efficient learning solution without data collection and transmission [19].

In contrast with centralized learning solutions, FL decouples the machine learning task from the central server to each edge node to avoid storing user data in the server and reduce the communication consumption. All of edge nodes make up a federation in coordination with the central server. In FL, each edge node performs local update and transmits its model parameter to the central server after a certain update interval. The central server integrates the received parameters to obtain a globally updated parameter, and sends this parameter back to all the edge nodes for next update interval.

The FL design and convergence analysis are presented in [21] where FL network is studied thoroughly. In an FL system, each edge node uses the same machine learning model. We use τ𝜏\tau to denote the global aggregation frequency, i.e., the update interval. Each node i𝑖i has its local model parameter w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t), where the iteration index is denoted by t=0,1,2,…𝑡012…t=0,1,2,... (in this paper, an iteration means a local update). We use [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k] to denote the aggregation interval [(k−1)​τ,k​τ]𝑘1𝜏𝑘𝜏[(k-1)\tau,k\tau] for k=1,2,3,…𝑘123…k=1,2,3,.... At t=0𝑡0t=0, local model parameters of all nodes are initialized to the same value. When t>0𝑡0t>0, w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t) is updated locally based on GD, which is the local update. After τ𝜏\tau local updates, global aggregation is performed and all edge nodes send the updated model parameters to the centralized server synchronously.

The learning process of FL is described as follows.

III-B1 Local Update

When t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], local updates are performed in each edge node by

w~i​(t)=w~i​(t−1)−η​∇Fi​(w~i​(t−1)),subscript~w𝑖𝑡subscript~w𝑖𝑡1𝜂∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript~w𝑖𝑡1\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t)=\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t-1)-\eta\nabla F_{i}(\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t-1)),

which follows GD exactly.

III-B2 Global Aggregation

When t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau, global aggregation is performed. Each node sends w~i​(k​τ)subscript~w𝑖𝑘𝜏\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(k\tau) to the central server synchronously. The central server takes a weighted average of the received parameters from N𝑁N nodes to obtain the globally updated parameter w​(k​τ)w𝑘𝜏\textbf{w}(k\tau) by

w​(k​τ)=∑i=1N|𝒟i|​w~i​(k​τ)|𝒟|.w𝑘𝜏superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖subscript~w𝑖𝑘𝜏𝒟\textbf{w}(k\tau)=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(k\tau)}{|\mathcal{D}|}.

Then w​(k​τ)w𝑘𝜏\textbf{w}(k\tau) is sent back to all edge nodes as their new parameters and edge nodes perform local update for the next iteration interval.

In [21, Lemma 2], the FL solution has been proven to be globally convergent for convex optimization problems and exhibits good convergence performance. So FL is an effective solution to the distributed learning problem presented in (1).

IV Design of MFL

In this section, we introduce the design of MFL to solve the distributed learning problem shown in (1). We first discuss the motivation of our work. Then we present the design of MFL detailedly and the learning problem based on federated system. The main notations of MFL design and analysis are summarized in Table I.

IV-A Motivation

Since MGD improves the convergence rate of GD [29], we want to apply MGD to local update steps of FL and hope that the proposed MFL will accelerate the convergence rate for federated networks.

Firstly, we illustrate the intuitive influence on optimization problem after introducing the momentum term into gradient updating methods. Considering GD, the update reduction of the parameter is η​∇F​(w​(t−1))𝜂∇𝐹w𝑡1\eta\nabla F(\textbf{w}(t-1)) which is only proportional to the gradient of w​(t−1)w𝑡1\textbf{w}(t-1). The update direction of GD is always along gradient descent so that an oscillating update path could be caused, as shown by the GD update path in Fig. 2. However, the update reduction of parameter for MGD is a superposition of η​∇F​(w​(t−1))𝜂∇𝐹w𝑡1\eta\nabla F(\textbf{w}(t-1)) and γ​(w​(t−2)−w​(t−1))𝛾w𝑡2w𝑡1\gamma(\textbf{w}(t-2)-\textbf{w}(t-1)) which is the momentum term. As shown by the MGD update path in Fig. 2, utilizing the momentum term can deviate the direction of parameter update to the optimal decline significantly and mitigate the oscillation caused by GD. In Fig. 2, GD has an oscillating update path and costs seven iterations to reach the optimal point while MGD only needs three iterations to do that, which demonstrates mitigating the oscillation by MGD leads to a faster convergence rate.

Because edge nodes of distributed networks are usually resource-constrained, solutions to convergence acceleration can attain higher resources utilization efficiency. Thus, motivated by the property that MGD improves convergence rate, we use MGD to perform local update of FL and this approach is named MFL.

In the following subsections, we design the MFL learning paradigm and propose the learning problem based on the MFL design.

IV-B MFL

In the MFL design, we use d~i​(t)subscript~d𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t) and w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t) to denote momentum parameter and model parameter for node i𝑖i, respectively. All edge nodes are set to embed the same machine learning models. So the local loss functions Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textbf{w}) is the same for all nodes, and the dimension of both the model parameters and the momentum parameters are consistent. The parameters setup of MFL is similar to that of FL. We use t𝑡t to denote the local iteration index for t=0,1,…𝑡01…t=0,1,..., τ𝜏\tau to denote the aggregation frequency and [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k] to denote the interval [(k−1)​τ,k​τ]𝑘1𝜏𝑘𝜏[(k-1)\tau,k\tau] where k𝑘k denotes the interval index for k=1,2,…𝑘12…k=1,2,.... At t=0𝑡0t=0, the momentum parameters and the model parameters of all nodes are initialized to the same values, respectively. When t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], d~i​(t)subscript~d𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t) and w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t) are updated based on MGD, which is called local update steps. When t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau, MFL performs global aggregation steps where d~i​(t)subscript~d𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t) and w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t) are sent to the central server synchronously. Then in the central server, the global momentum parameter d​(t)d𝑡\textbf{d}(t) and the global model parameter w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) are obtained by taking a weighted average of the received parameters, respectively, and are sent back to all edge nodes for the next interval.

The learning rules of MFL include the local update and the global aggregation steps. By continuous alternations of local update and global aggregation, MFL can perform its learning process to minimize the global loss function F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}). We describe the MFL learning process as follows.

First of all, we set initial values for d~i​(0)subscript~d𝑖0\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(0) and w~i​(0)subscript~w𝑖0\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(0). Then

1) Local Update: When t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], local update is performed at each edge node by

d~i​(t)subscript~d𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t) =γ​d~i​(t−1)+∇Fi​(w~i​(t−1))absent𝛾subscript~d𝑖𝑡1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscript~w𝑖𝑡1\displaystyle=\gamma\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t-1)+\nabla F_{i}(\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t-1)) (6)
w~i​(t)subscript~w𝑖𝑡\displaystyle\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t) =w~i​(t−1)−η​d~i​(t).absentsubscript~w𝑖𝑡1𝜂subscript~d𝑖𝑡\displaystyle=\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t-1)-\eta\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t). (7)

According to (6) and (7), node i𝑖i performs MGD to optimize the loss function Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) defined on its own dataset.

2) Global Aggregation: When t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau, node i𝑖i transmits w~i​(k​τ)subscript~w𝑖𝑘𝜏\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(k\tau) and d~i​(k​τ)subscript~d𝑖𝑘𝜏\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(k\tau) to the central server which takes weighted averages of the received parameters from N𝑁N nodes to obtain the global parameters w​(k​τ)w𝑘𝜏\textbf{w}(k\tau) and d​(k​τ)d𝑘𝜏\textbf{d}(k\tau), respectively. The aggregation rules are presented as follows:

d​(t)d𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{d}(t) =∑i=1N|𝒟i|​d~i​(t)|𝒟|absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖subscript~d𝑖𝑡𝒟\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(t)}{|\mathcal{D}|} (8)
w​(t)w𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{w}(t) =∑i=1N|𝒟i|​w~i​(t)|𝒟|.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝒟𝑖subscript~w𝑖𝑡𝒟\displaystyle=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{N}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t)}{|\mathcal{D}|}. (9)

Then the central server sends d​(k​τ)d𝑘𝜏\textbf{d}(k\tau) and w​(k​τ)w𝑘𝜏\textbf{w}(k\tau) back to all edge nodes where d~i​(k​τ)=d​(k​τ)subscript~d𝑖𝑘𝜏d𝑘𝜏\widetilde{\textbf{d}}_{i}(k\tau)=\textbf{d}(k\tau) and w~i​(k​τ)=w​(k​τ)subscript~w𝑖𝑘𝜏w𝑘𝜏\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(k\tau)=\textbf{w}(k\tau) are set to enable the local update in the next interval [k+1]delimited-[]𝑘1[k+1]. Note that only if t=k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t=k\tau, the value of the global parameters w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) and d​(t)d𝑡\textbf{d}(t) can be observed. But we define d​(t)d𝑡\textbf{d}(t) and w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) for all t𝑡t to facilitate the following analysis. A typical alternation are shown in Fig. 3 which intuitively illustrates the learning steps of MFL in interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k] and [k+1]delimited-[]𝑘1[k+1].

The learning problem of MFL to attain the optimal model parameter is presented as (1). However, the edge nodes have limited computation resources with a finite number of local iterations. We assume that T𝑇T is the number of local iterations and K𝐾K is the corresponding number of global aggregations. Thus, we have t≤T𝑡𝑇t\leq T and k≤K𝑘𝐾k\leq K with T=K​τ𝑇𝐾𝜏T=K\tau. Considering that w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) is unobservable for t≠k​τ𝑡𝑘𝜏t\neq k\tau, we use wfsuperscriptwf\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}} to denote the achievable optimal model parameter defined on resource-constrained MFL network. Hence, the learning problem is to obtain wfsuperscriptwf\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}} within T𝑇T local iterations particularly, i.e.,

wf≜arg⁡minw∈{w​(k​τ):k=1,2,…,K}F​(w).≜superscriptwfsubscriptwconditional-setw𝑘𝜏𝑘12…𝐾𝐹w\displaystyle\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}}\triangleq\mathop{\arg\min}_{\textbf{w}\in\{\textbf{w}(k\tau):k=1,2,...,K\}}F(\textbf{w}). (10)

The optimization algorithm of MFL is explained in Algorithm 1.

V Convergence Analysis

In this section, we firstly make some definitions and assumptions for MFL convergence analysis. Then based on these preliminaries, global convergence properties of MFL following Algorithm 1 are established and an upper bound on MFL convergence rate is derived. Also MFL convergence performance with related parameters is analyzed.

V-A Preliminaries

First of all, to facilitate the analysis, we assume that Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textbf{w}) satisfies the following conditions:

Assumption 1.

For Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) in node i𝑖i, we assume the following conditions:
1) Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) is convex
2) Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, i.e., |Fi​(w1)−Fi​(w2)|≤ρ​‖w1−w2‖subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw1subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw2𝜌normsubscriptw1subscriptw2|F_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{1})-F_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{2})|\leq\rho\|\textup{{w}}_{1}-\textup{{w}}_{2}\| for some ρ>0𝜌0\rho>0 and any w1subscriptw1\textup{{w}}_{1}, w2subscriptw2\textup{{w}}_{2}
3) Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) is β𝛽\beta-smooth, i.e., ‖∇Fi​(w1)−∇Fi​(w2)‖≤β​‖w1−w2‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw1∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw2𝛽normsubscriptw1subscriptw2\|\nabla F_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{1})-\nabla F_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{2})\|\leq\beta\|\textup{{w}}_{1}-\textup{{w}}_{2}\| for some β>0𝛽0\beta>0 and any w1subscriptw1\textup{{w}}_{1}, w2subscriptw2\textup{{w}}_{2}
4) Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textup{{w}}) is μ𝜇\mu-strong, i.e., a​Fi​(w1)+(1−a)​Fi​(w2)≥Fi​(a​w1+(1−a)​w2)+a​(1−a)​μ2​‖w1−w2‖2𝑎subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw11𝑎subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw2subscript𝐹𝑖𝑎subscriptw11𝑎subscriptw2𝑎1𝑎𝜇2superscriptnormsubscriptw1subscriptw22aF_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{1})+(1-a)F_{i}(\textup{{w}}_{2})\geq F_{i}(a\textup{{w}}_{1}+(1-a)\textup{{w}}_{2})+\frac{a(1-a)\mu}{2}\|\textup{{w}}_{1}-\textup{{w}}_{2}\|^{2}, a∈[0,1]𝑎01a\in[0,1] for some μ>0𝜇0\mu>0 and any w1subscriptw1\textup{{w}}_{1}, w2subscriptw2\textup{{w}}_{2} [32, Theorem 2.1.9]

Because guaranteeing the global convergence of centralized MGD requires that the objective function is strongly convex [29], it is necessary to assume the condition 4. Assumption 1 is satisfied for some learning models such as support vector machine (SVM), linear regression and logistic regression whose loss functions are presented in Table II. From Assumption 1, we can obtain the following lemma:

Lemma 1.

F​(w)𝐹wF(\textup{{w}}) is convex, ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, β𝛽\beta-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strong.

Proof.

According to the definition of F​(w)𝐹wF(\textup{{w}}) from (2), triangle inequality and the definition of ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, β𝛽\beta-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strong, we can derive that F​(w)𝐹wF(\textup{{w}}) is convex, ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz, β𝛽\beta-smooth and μ𝜇\mu-strong directly. ∎

Then we introduce the gradient divergence between ∇F​(w)∇𝐹w\nabla F(\textbf{w}) and ∇Fi​(w)∇subscript𝐹𝑖w\nabla F_{i}(\textbf{w}) for any node i𝑖i. It comes from the nature of the difference in datasets distribution.

Definition 2 (Gradient divergence).

We define δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} as the upper bound between ∇F​(w)∇𝐹w\nabla F(\textup{{w}}) and ∇Fi​(w)∇subscript𝐹𝑖w\nabla F_{i}(\textup{{w}}) for any node i𝑖i, i.e.,

‖∇F​(w)−∇Fi​(w)‖≤δi.norm∇𝐹w∇subscript𝐹𝑖wsubscript𝛿𝑖\displaystyle\|\nabla F(\textup{{w}})-\nabla F_{i}(\textup{{w}})\|\leq\delta_{i}. (11)

Also, we define the average gradient divergence

δ≜∑i|𝒟i|​δi|𝒟|.≜𝛿subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑖subscript𝛿𝑖𝒟\displaystyle\delta\triangleq\frac{\sum_{i}|\mathcal{D}_{i}|\delta_{i}}{|\mathcal{D}|}. (12)

Boundedness of δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} and δ𝛿\delta: Based on condition 3 of Assumption 1, we let w2=wi∗subscriptw2superscriptsubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{2}=\textbf{w}_{i}^{*} where wi∗superscriptsubscriptw𝑖\textbf{w}_{i}^{*} is the optimal value for minimizing Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textbf{w}). Because Fi​(w)subscript𝐹𝑖wF_{i}(\textbf{w}) is convex, we have ‖∇Fi​(w1)‖≤β​‖w1−wi∗‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖subscriptw1𝛽normsubscriptw1superscriptsubscriptw𝑖\|\nabla F_{i}(\textbf{w}_{1})\|\leq\beta\|\textbf{w}_{1}-\textbf{w}_{i}^{*}\| for any w1subscriptw1\textbf{w}_{1}, which means ‖∇Fi​(w)‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖w\|\nabla F_{i}(\textbf{w})\| is finite for any w. According to Definition 1 and the linearity of gradient operator, global loss function ∇F​(w)∇𝐹w\nabla F(\textbf{w}) is obtained by taking a weighted average of ∇Fi​(w)∇subscript𝐹𝑖w\nabla F_{i}(\textbf{w}). Therefore, ‖∇F​(w)‖norm∇𝐹w\|\nabla F(\textbf{w})\| is finite, and ‖∇F​(w)−∇Fi​(w)‖norm∇𝐹w∇subscript𝐹𝑖w\|\nabla F(\textup{{w}})-\nabla F_{i}(\textup{{w}})\| has an upper bound, i.e., δisubscript𝛿𝑖\delta_{i} is bounded. Further, δ𝛿\delta is still bounded from the linearity in (12).

Since local update steps of MFL perform MGD, the upper bounds of MFL and MGD convergence rate exist certain connections in the same interval. For the convenience of analysis, we use variables d[k]​(t)subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t) and w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) to denote the momentum parameter and the model parameter of centralized MGD in each interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], respectively. This centralized MGD is defined on global dataset and updated based on global loss function F​(w)𝐹wF(\textbf{w}). In interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], the update rules of centralized MGD follow:

d[k]​(t)subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t) =γ​d[k]​(t−1)+∇F​(w[k]​(t−1))absent𝛾subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡1∇𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡1\displaystyle=\gamma\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t-1)+\nabla F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t-1)) (13)
w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\displaystyle\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) =w[k]​(t−1)−η​d[k]​(t).absentsubscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡1𝜂subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\displaystyle=\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t-1)-\eta\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t). (14)

At the beginning of interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], the momentum parameter d[k]​(t)subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t) and the model parameter w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) of centralized MGD are synchronized with the corresponding parameters of MFL, i.e.,

d[k]​((k−1)​τ)≜d​((k−1)​τ)≜subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑘1𝜏d𝑘1𝜏\displaystyle\textbf{d}_{[k]}((k-1)\tau)\triangleq\textbf{d}((k-1)\tau)
w[k]​((k−1)​τ)≜w​((k−1)​τ).≜subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘1𝜏w𝑘1𝜏\displaystyle\textbf{w}_{[k]}((k-1)\tau)\triangleq\textbf{w}((k-1)\tau).

For each interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], the centralized MGD is performed by iterations of (13) and (14). In the Fig. 4, we illustrate the distinctions between F​(w​(t))𝐹w𝑡F(\textbf{w}(t)) and F​(w[k]​(t))𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t)) intuitively.

Comparing with centralized MGD, MFL aggregation interval with τ>1𝜏1\tau>1 brings global update delay because of the fact that centralized MGD performs global update on every iteration while MFL is allowed to spread its global parameter to edge nodes after τ𝜏\tau local updates. Therefore, the convergence performance of MFL is worse than that of MGD, which is essentially from the imbalance between several computation rounds and one communication round in MFL design. The following subsection provides the resulting convergence performance gap between these two approaches.

V-B Gap between MFL and Centralized MGD in Interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k]

Firstly, considering a special case, we consider the gap between MFL and centralized MGD for τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. From physical perspective, MFL performs global aggregation after every local update and there does not exist global parameter update delay, i.e, the performance gap is zero. In Appendix A, we prove that MFL is equivalent to MGD for τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 from theoretical perspective.

Now considering general case for any τ≥1𝜏1\tau\geq 1, the upper bound of gap between w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) and w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) can be derived as follows.

Proposition 1 (Gap of MFL&\&centralized MGD in intervals).

Given t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], the gap between w​(t)w𝑡\textup{{w}}(t) and w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(t) can be expressed by

‖w​(t)−w[k]​(t)‖≤h​(t−(k−1)​τ),normw𝑡subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡ℎ𝑡𝑘1𝜏\displaystyle\|\textup{{w}}(t)-\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(t)\|\leq h(t-(k-1)\tau), (15)

where we define

A𝐴\displaystyle A ≜(1+γ+η​β)+(1+γ+η​β)2−4​γ2​γ,≜absent1𝛾𝜂𝛽superscript1𝛾𝜂𝛽24𝛾2𝛾\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{(1\!+\!\gamma+\!\eta\beta)\!+\!\sqrt{(1\!+\!\gamma\!+\!\eta\beta)^{2}\!-\!4\gamma}}{2\gamma},
B𝐵\displaystyle B ≜(1+γ+η​β)−(1+γ+η​β)2−4​γ2​γ,≜absent1𝛾𝜂𝛽superscript1𝛾𝜂𝛽24𝛾2𝛾\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{(1\!+\!\gamma+\!\eta\beta)\!-\!\sqrt{(1\!+\!\gamma\!+\!\eta\beta)^{2}\!-\!4\gamma}}{2\gamma},
E𝐸\displaystyle E ≜A(A−B)​(γ​A−1),≜absent𝐴𝐴𝐵𝛾𝐴1\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{A}{(A-B)(\gamma A-1)},
F𝐹\displaystyle F ≜B(A−B)​(1−γ​B)≜absent𝐵𝐴𝐵1𝛾𝐵\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{B}{(A-B)(1-\gamma B)}

and h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x) yields

h​(x)ℎ𝑥\displaystyle h(x) =η​δ​[E​(γ​A)x+F​(γ​B)x−1η​β−γ​(γx−1)−(γ−1)​x(γ−1)2]absent𝜂𝛿delimited-[]𝐸superscript𝛾𝐴𝑥𝐹superscript𝛾𝐵𝑥1𝜂𝛽𝛾superscript𝛾𝑥1𝛾1𝑥superscript𝛾12\displaystyle\!=\!\eta\delta\left[E(\gamma A)^{x}\!+\!F(\gamma B)^{x}\!-\!\frac{1}{\eta\beta}\!-\!\frac{\gamma(\gamma^{x}-1)-(\gamma-1)x}{(\gamma-1)^{2}}\right] (16)

for 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1 and any x=0,1,2,…𝑥012…x=0,1,2,....

Because F​(w)𝐹wF(\textup{{w}}) is ρ𝜌\rho-Lipschitz from Lemma 1, it holds that

F​(w​(t))−F​(w[k]​(t))≤ρ​h​(t−(k−1)​τ).𝐹w𝑡𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡𝜌ℎ𝑡𝑘1𝜏\displaystyle F(\textup{{w}}(t))-F(\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(t))\leq\rho h(t-(k-1)\tau). (17)
Proof.

Firstly, we derive an upper bound of ‖w~i​(t)−w[k]​(t)‖normsubscript~w𝑖𝑡subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\|\widetilde{\textbf{w}}_{i}(t)-\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t)\| for node i𝑖i. On the basis of this bound, we extend this result from the local cases to the global one to obtain the final result. The detailed proving process is presented in Appendix B. ∎

Because h​(1)=h​(0)=0ℎ1ℎ00h(1)=h(0)=0 and h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x) increases with x𝑥x for x≥1𝑥1x\geq 1, which are proven in Appendix C, we always have h​(x)≥0ℎ𝑥0h(x)\geq 0 for x=0,1,2,…𝑥012…x=0,1,2,....

From Proposition 1, in any interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], we have h​(0)=0ℎ00h(0)=0 for t=(k−1)​τ𝑡𝑘1𝜏t=(k-1)\tau, which fits the definition w[k]​((k−1)​τ)=w​((k−1)​τ)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘1𝜏w𝑘1𝜏\textbf{w}_{[k]}((k-1)\tau)=\textbf{w}((k-1)\tau). We still have h​(1)=0ℎ10h(1)=0 for t=(k−1)​τ+1𝑡𝑘1𝜏1t=(k-1)\tau+1. This means that there is no gap between MFL and centralized MGD when local update is only performed once after the global aggregation.

It is easy to find that if τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, t−(k−1)​τ𝑡𝑘1𝜏t-(k-1)\tau is either 0 or 1. Because h​(1)=h​(0)=0ℎ1ℎ00h(1)=h(0)=0, the upper bound in (15) is zero, and there is no gap between F​(w​(t))𝐹w𝑡F(\textup{{w}}(t)) and F​(w[k]​(t))𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡F(\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(t)) from (17). This is consistent with Appendix A where MFL yields centralized MGD for τ=1𝜏1\tau=1. In any interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], we have t−(k−1)​τ∈[0,τ]𝑡𝑘1𝜏0𝜏t-(k-1)\tau\in[0,\tau]. If τ>1𝜏1\tau>1, t−(k−1)​τ𝑡𝑘1𝜏t-(k-1)\tau can be larger than 1. When x>1𝑥1x>1, we know that h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x) increases with x𝑥x. According to the definition of A𝐴A, B𝐵B, E𝐸E and F𝐹F, we can obtain γ​A>1𝛾𝐴1\gamma A>1, γ​B<1𝛾𝐵1\gamma B<1 and E,F>0𝐸𝐹0E,F>0 easily. Because 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1, the last term will linearly decrease with x𝑥x when x𝑥x is large. Therefore, the first exponential term E​(γ​A)x𝐸superscript𝛾𝐴𝑥E(\gamma A)^{x} in (16) will be dominant when x𝑥x is large and the gap between w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) and w[k]​(t)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) increases exponentially with t𝑡t.

Also we find h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x) is proportional to the average gradient gap δ𝛿\delta. It is because the greater the local gradient divergences at different nodes are, the larger the gap will be. So considering the extreme situation where all nodes have the same data samples (δ=0𝛿0\delta=0 because the local loss function are the same), the gap between w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) and w​(t)w𝑡\textbf{w}(t) is zero and MFL is equivalent to centralized MGD.

V-C Global Convergence

We have derived an upper bound between F​(w​(t))𝐹w𝑡F(\textup{{w}}(t)) and F​(w[k]​(t))𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡F(\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(t)) for t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k]. According to the definition of MFL, in the beginning of each interval [k]delimited-[]𝑘[k], we set d[k]​((k−1)​τ)=d​((k−1)​τ)subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑘1𝜏d𝑘1𝜏\textbf{d}_{[k]}((k-1)\tau)=\textbf{d}((k-1)\tau) and w[k]​((k−1)​τ)=w​((k−1)​τ)subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘1𝜏w𝑘1𝜏\textbf{w}_{[k]}((k-1)\tau)=\textbf{w}((k-1)\tau). The global upper bound on the convergence rate of MFL can be derived based on Proposition 1.

The following definitions are made to facilitate analysis. Firstly, we use θ[k]​(t)subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑘𝑡\theta_{[k]}(t) to denote the angle between vector ∇F(w[k](t)\nabla F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t) and d[k]​(t)subscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t) for t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], i.e.,

cos⁡θ[k]​(t)≜∇F​(w[k]​(t))T​d[k]​(t)∥∇F(w[k](t)∥∥d[k](t)∥\cos\theta_{[k]}(t)\triangleq\frac{\nabla F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t))^{\mathrm{T}}\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t)}{\|\nabla F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t)\|\|\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t)\|}

where θ𝜃\theta is defined as the maximum value of θ[k]​(t)subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑘𝑡\theta_{[k]}(t) for 1≤k≤K1𝑘𝐾1\leq k\leq K with t∈[k]𝑡delimited-[]𝑘t\in[k], i.e.,

θ≜max1≤k≤K,t∈[k]⁡θ[k]​(t).≜𝜃subscriptformulae-sequence1𝑘𝐾𝑡delimited-[]𝑘subscript𝜃delimited-[]𝑘𝑡\theta\triangleq\max_{1\leq k\leq K,t\in[k]}\theta_{[k]}(t).

Then we define

p≜max1≤k≤K,t∈[k]⁡‖d[k]​(t)‖‖∇F​(w[k]​(t))‖≜𝑝subscriptformulae-sequence1𝑘𝐾𝑡delimited-[]𝑘normsubscriptddelimited-[]𝑘𝑡norm∇𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑡p\triangleq\max_{1\leq k\leq K,t\in[k]}\frac{\|\textbf{d}_{[k]}(t)\|}{\|\nabla F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(t))\|}

and

ω≜mink⁡1‖w​((k−1)​τ)−w∗‖2.≜𝜔subscript𝑘1superscriptnormw𝑘1𝜏superscriptw2\omega\triangleq\min_{k}\frac{1}{\|\textbf{w}((k-1)\tau)-\textbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}}.

Based on Proposition 1 which gives an upper bound of loss function difference between MFL and centralized MGD, global convergence rate of MFL can be derived as follows.

Lemma 2.

If the following conditions are satisfied:
1) cos⁡θ≥0𝜃0\cos\theta\geq 0, 0<η​β<10𝜂𝛽10<\eta\beta<1 and 0≤γ<10𝛾10\leq\gamma<1;
There exists ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0 which makes
2) F​(w[k]​(k​τ))−F​(w∗)≥ε𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘𝜏𝐹superscriptw𝜀F(\textup{{w}}_{[k]}(k\tau))-F(\textup{{w}}^{*})\geq\varepsilon for all k𝑘k;
3) F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)≥ε𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptw𝜀F(\textup{{w}}(T))-F(\textup{{w}}^{*})\geq\varepsilon;
4) ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε2>0𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscript𝜀20\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon^{2}}>0 hold,
then we have

F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)≤1T​(ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε2)𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptw1𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscript𝜀2\displaystyle F(\textup{{w}}(T))-F(\textup{{w}}^{*})\leq\frac{1}{T\left(\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon^{2}}\right)} (18)

where we defined

α≜η​(1−β​η2)+η​γ​(1−β​η)​cos⁡θ−β​η2​γ2​p22.≜𝛼𝜂1𝛽𝜂2𝜂𝛾1𝛽𝜂𝜃𝛽superscript𝜂2superscript𝛾2superscript𝑝22\alpha\triangleq\!\eta(1\!-\!\frac{\beta\eta}{2})\!+\!\eta\gamma(1-\beta\eta)\cos\theta\!-\!\frac{\beta\eta^{2}\gamma^{2}p^{2}}{2}.
Proof.

The proof is presented in Appendix D. ∎

On the basis of Lemma 2, we further derive the following proposition which demonstrates the global convergence of MFL and gives its upper bound on convergence rate.

Proposition 2 (MFL global convergence).

Given cos⁡θ≥0𝜃0\cos\theta\geq 0, 0<η​β<10𝜂𝛽10<\eta\beta<1, 0≤γ<10𝛾10\leq\gamma<1 and α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, we have

F​(wf)−F​(w∗)≤12​T​ω​α+14​T2​ω2​α2+ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τ+ρ​h​(τ).𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptw12𝑇𝜔𝛼14superscript𝑇2superscript𝜔2superscript𝛼2𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏\displaystyle F(\textup{{w}}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textup{{w}}^{*})\leq\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4T^{2}\omega^{2}\alpha^{2}}+\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}+\rho h(\tau). (19)
Proof.

The specific proving process is shown in Appendix E. ∎

According to the above Proposition 2, we get an upper bound of F​(wf)−F​(w∗)𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptwF(\textup{{w}}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textup{{w}}^{*}) which is a function of T𝑇T and τ𝜏\tau. From inequality (19), we can find that MFL linearly converges to a lower bound ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τ+ρ​h​(τ)𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏\sqrt{\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}+\rho h(\tau). Because h​(τ)ℎ𝜏h(\tau) is related to τ𝜏\tau and δ𝛿\delta, aggregation intervals (τ>1𝜏1\tau>1) and different data distribution collectively lead to that MFL does not converge to the optimum.

In the following, we discuss the influence of τ𝜏\tau on the convergence bound. If τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, we have ρ​h​(τ)=0𝜌ℎ𝜏0\rho h(\tau)=0 so that F​(wf)−F​(w∗)𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptwF(\textup{{w}}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textup{{w}}^{*}) linearly converges to zero as T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty, and the convergence rate yields 1T​ω​α1𝑇𝜔𝛼\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha}. Noting h​(τ)>0ℎ𝜏0h(\tau)>0 if τ>1𝜏1\tau>1, we can find that in this case, F​(wf)−F​(w∗)𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptwF(\textup{{w}}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textup{{w}}^{*}) converges to a non-zero bound ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τ+ρ​h​(τ)𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏\sqrt{\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}+\rho h(\tau) as T→∞→𝑇T\to\infty. On the one hand, if there does not exist communication resources limit, setting aggregation frequency τ=1𝜏1\tau=1 and performing global aggregation after each local update can reach the optimal convergence performance of MFL. On the other hand, aggregation interval (τ>1𝜏1\tau>1) can let MFL effectively utilize the communication resources of each node, but bring about a decline of convergence performance.

VI Comparison Between FL and MFL

In this section, we make a comparison of convergence performance between MFL and FL.

The closed-form solution of the upper bound on FL convergence rate has been derived in [21, Theorem 2]. It is presented as follows.

F​(wF​Lf)−F​(w∗)≤12​η​φ​T+14​η2​φ2​T2+ρ​hF​L​(τ)η​φ​τ+ρ​hF​L​(τ).𝐹superscriptsubscriptw𝐹𝐿f𝐹superscriptw12𝜂𝜑𝑇14superscript𝜂2superscript𝜑2superscript𝑇2𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏\displaystyle F(\textbf{w}_{F\!L}^{\mathrm{f}})\!-\!F(\textup{{w}}^{*})\!\leq\!\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T}\!+\!\sqrt{\frac{1}{4\eta^{2}\varphi^{2}T^{2}}\!+\!\frac{\rho h_{F\!L}(\tau)}{\eta\varphi\tau}}\!+\!\rho h_{F\!L}(\tau). (20)

According to [21],

hF​L​(τ)=δβ​((η​β+1)τ−1)−η​δ​τsubscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝛿𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝜏1𝜂𝛿𝜏h_{F\!L}(\tau)=\frac{\delta}{\beta}((\eta\beta+1)^{\tau}-1)-\eta\delta\tau

and φ=ωF​L​(1−η​β2)𝜑subscript𝜔𝐹𝐿1𝜂𝛽2\varphi=\omega_{F\!L}(1-\frac{\eta\beta}{2}) where the expression of ωF​Lsubscript𝜔𝐹𝐿\omega_{FL} is consistent with ω𝜔\omega. Differing from that of ω𝜔\omega, w​((k−1)​τ)w𝑘1𝜏\textbf{w}((k-1)\tau) in the definition of ωF​Lsubscript𝜔𝐹𝐿\omega_{FL} is the global model parameter of FL.

We assume that both MFL and FL solutions are applied in the system model proposed in Fig. 1. They are trained based on the same training dataset with the same machine learning model. The loss function Fi​(⋅)subscript𝐹𝑖⋅F_{i}(\cdot) and global loss function F​(⋅)𝐹⋅F(\cdot) of MFL and FL are the same, respective. The corresponding parameters of MFL and FL are equivalent including τ𝜏\tau, η𝜂\eta, ρ𝜌\rho, δ𝛿\delta and β𝛽\beta. We set the same initial value w​(0)w0\textbf{w}(0) of MFL and FL. Because both MFL and FL are convergent, we have ω=1‖w​(0)−w∗‖2𝜔1superscriptnormw0superscriptw2\omega=\frac{1}{\|\textbf{w}(0)-\textbf{w}^{*}\|^{2}}. Then according to the definitions of ω𝜔\omega and ωF​Lsubscript𝜔𝐹𝐿\omega_{F\!L}, we have w=wF​L𝑤subscript𝑤𝐹𝐿w=w_{F\!L}. Therefore, the corresponding parameters of MFL and FL are the same and we can compare the convergences between FL and MFL conveniently.

For convenience, we use f1​(T)subscript𝑓1𝑇f_{1}(T) and f2​(T)subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{2}(T) to denote the upper bound on convergence rate of MFL and FL, respectively. Then we have

f1​(T)≜12​T​ω​α+14​T2​ω2​α2+ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τ+ρ​h​(τ)≜subscript𝑓1𝑇12𝑇𝜔𝛼14superscript𝑇2superscript𝜔2superscript𝛼2𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏\displaystyle f_{1}(T)\triangleq\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4T^{2}\omega^{2}\alpha^{2}}+\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}+\rho h(\tau) (21)

and

f2​(T)≜12​η​φ​T+14​η2​φ2​T2+ρ​hF​L​(τ)η​φ​τ+ρ​hF​L​(τ).≜subscript𝑓2𝑇12𝜂𝜑𝑇14superscript𝜂2superscript𝜑2superscript𝑇2𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜂𝜑𝜏𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏\displaystyle f_{2}(T)\triangleq\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T}\!+\!\sqrt{\frac{1}{4\eta^{2}\varphi^{2}T^{2}}\!+\!\frac{\rho h_{F\!L}(\tau)}{\eta\varphi\tau}}\!+\!\rho h_{F\!L}(\tau). (22)

We consider the special case of γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0. For ω​α𝜔𝛼\omega\alpha and η​φ𝜂𝜑\eta\varphi, we can obtain ω​α→ω​η​(1−β​η2)=η​φ→𝜔𝛼𝜔𝜂1𝛽𝜂2𝜂𝜑\omega\alpha\to\omega\eta(1-\frac{\beta\eta}{2})=\eta\varphi from the definition of α𝛼\alpha. Then for h​(τ)ℎ𝜏h(\tau) and hF​L​(τ)subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏h_{FL}(\tau), we have γ​A→η​β+1→𝛾𝐴𝜂𝛽1\gamma A\to\eta\beta+1 and γ​B→0→𝛾𝐵0\gamma B\to 0. Because AA−B→1→𝐴𝐴𝐵1\frac{A}{A-B}\to 1 and BA−B→0→𝐵𝐴𝐵0\frac{B}{A-B}\to 0, we can further get E→1η​β→𝐸1𝜂𝛽E\to\frac{1}{\eta\beta} and F→0→𝐹0F\to 0 from the definitions of E𝐸E and F𝐹F. So, according to (16), we have

limγ→0h​(τ)subscript→𝛾0ℎ𝜏\displaystyle\lim_{\gamma\to 0}h(\tau) =η​δ​[1η​β​(η​β+1)τ−1η​β−τ]absent𝜂𝛿delimited-[]1𝜂𝛽superscript𝜂𝛽1𝜏1𝜂𝛽𝜏\displaystyle=\eta\delta\left[\frac{1}{\eta\beta}(\eta\beta+1)^{\tau}\!-\!\frac{1}{\eta\beta}\!-\tau\right]
=δβ​((1+η​β)τ−1)−η​δ​τ=hF​L​(τ).absent𝛿𝛽superscript1𝜂𝛽𝜏1𝜂𝛿𝜏subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏\displaystyle=\frac{\delta}{\beta}((1+\eta\beta)^{\tau}-1)-\eta\delta\tau=h_{FL}(\tau).

Hence, by the above analysis under γ→0→𝛾0\gamma\to 0, we can find MFL and FL have the same upper bound on convergence rate. This fact is consistent with the property that if γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, MFL degenerates into FL and has the same convergence rate with FL.

To avoid complicated calculations over the expressions of f1​(T)subscript𝑓1𝑇f_{1}(T) and f2​(T)subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{2}(T), we consider the special case of small η𝜂\eta (η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0) which is typically used in simulations.

Lemma 3.

If η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0, existing T1≥1subscript𝑇11T_{1}\geq 1, we have 12​T​ω​α12𝑇𝜔𝛼\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha} dominates in f1​(T)subscript𝑓1𝑇f_{1}(T) and 12​η​φ​T12𝜂𝜑𝑇\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T} dominates in f2​(T)subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{2}(T) for T<T1𝑇subscript𝑇1T<T_{1}, i.e.,

12​T​ω​α≫max⁡{ρ​h​(τ),ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τ}much-greater-than12𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha}\gg\max\left\{\rho h(\tau),\sqrt{\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}}\right\}

and

12​η​φ​T≫max⁡{ρ​hF​L​(τ),ρ​hF​L​(τ)η​φ​τ}.much-greater-than12𝜂𝜑𝑇𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜂𝜑𝜏\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T}\gg\max\left\{\rho h_{FL}(\tau),\sqrt{\frac{\rho h_{FL}(\tau)}{\eta\varphi\tau}}\right\}.

Then we have

f1​(T)≈1T​ω​αsubscript𝑓1𝑇1𝑇𝜔𝛼f_{1}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha}

and

f2​(T)≈1T​η​φsubscript𝑓2𝑇1𝑇𝜂𝜑f_{2}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\eta\varphi}

for T<T1𝑇subscript𝑇1T<T_{1}.

Proof.

Considering (21), if η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0, we have α→0→𝛼0\alpha\to 0 from the definition of α𝛼\alpha and h​(τ)→0→ℎ𝜏0h(\tau)\to 0 from Appendix F. So we can easily derive ω​α​ρ​h​(τ)→0→𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏0\omega\alpha\rho h(\tau)\to 0 and ω​α​ρ​h​(τ)τ→0→𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏0\sqrt{\frac{\omega\alpha\rho h(\tau)}{\tau}}\to 0. Then we can find T1≥1subscript𝑇11T_{1}\geq 1 which satisfies 12​T≫ω​α​ρ​h​(τ)much-greater-than12𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏\frac{1}{2T}\gg\omega\alpha\rho h(\tau) and 12​T≫ω​α​ρ​h​(τ)τmuch-greater-than12𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏\frac{1}{2T}\gg\sqrt{\frac{\omega\alpha\rho h(\tau)}{\tau}} for T<T1𝑇subscript𝑇1T<T_{1}. Hence, we have 12​T​ω​α12𝑇𝜔𝛼\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha} dominates in f1​(T)subscript𝑓1𝑇f_{1}(T) and f1​(T)≈1T​ω​αsubscript𝑓1𝑇1𝑇𝜔𝛼f_{1}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha}.

For the same reason, considering (22), if η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0, we have η​φ→0→𝜂𝜑0\eta\varphi\to 0 from the definition of φ𝜑\varphi and hF​L​(τ)→0→subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏0h_{FL}(\tau)\to 0 from its definition. So we can easily derive η​φ​ρ​hF​L​(τ)→0→𝜂𝜑𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏0\eta\varphi\rho h_{FL}(\tau)\to 0 and η​φ​ρ​hF​L​(τ)τ→0→𝜂𝜑𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜏0\sqrt{\frac{\eta\varphi\rho h_{FL}(\tau)}{\tau}}\to 0. Then for T<T1𝑇subscript𝑇1T<T_{1}, 12​T≫η​φ​ρ​hF​L​(τ)much-greater-than12𝑇𝜂𝜑𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏\frac{1}{2T}\gg\eta\varphi\rho h_{FL}(\tau) and 12​T≫η​φ​ρ​hF​L​(τ)τmuch-greater-than12𝑇𝜂𝜑𝜌subscriptℎ𝐹𝐿𝜏𝜏\frac{1}{2T}\gg\sqrt{\frac{\eta\varphi\rho h_{FL}(\tau)}{\tau}}. Hence, we have 12​η​φ​T12𝜂𝜑𝑇\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T} dominates in f2​(T)subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{2}(T) and f2​(T)≈1T​η​φsubscript𝑓2𝑇1𝑇𝜂𝜑f_{2}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\eta\varphi}. ∎

From Lemma 3, we can find that if the learning step size is small and the local update index is not too large, the influence of the update intervals on convergence rate can be ignored. So taking this property into account, we can set a small learning step size to cut down communication resources consumption by increasing computation resources cost.

Proposition 3 (Accelerated convergence of MFL).

If the following conditions are satisfied:
1) η→0→𝜂0\eta\to 0;
2) T<T1𝑇subscript𝑇1T<T_{1};
3) 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1,
MFL converges faster than FL, i.e.,

f1​(T)<f2​(T).subscript𝑓1𝑇subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{1}(T)<f_{2}(T).
Proof.

From condition 1 and condition 2, we have f1​(T)≈1T​ω​αsubscript𝑓1𝑇1𝑇𝜔𝛼f_{1}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha} and f2​(T)≈1T​η​φsubscript𝑓2𝑇1𝑇𝜂𝜑f_{2}(T)\approx\frac{1}{T\eta\varphi}. Due to the definition of α𝛼\alpha and φ𝜑\varphi, inequality 0<γ<2​(1−β​η)​cos⁡θβ​η​p20𝛾21𝛽𝜂𝜃𝛽𝜂superscript𝑝20<\gamma<\frac{2(1-\beta\eta)\cos\theta}{\beta\eta p^{2}} is equivalent to ω​α>η​φ𝜔𝛼𝜂𝜑\omega\alpha>\eta\varphi. So if ω​α>η​φ𝜔𝛼𝜂𝜑\omega\alpha>\eta\varphi, it is obvious that 1T​ω​α<1T​η​φ1𝑇𝜔𝛼1𝑇𝜂𝜑\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha}<\frac{1}{T\eta\varphi}, i.e., f1​(T)<f2​(T)subscript𝑓1𝑇subscript𝑓2𝑇f_{1}(T)<f_{2}(T). From condition 1, 2​(1−β​η)​cos⁡θβ​η​p221𝛽𝜂𝜃𝛽𝜂superscript𝑝2\frac{2(1-\beta\eta)\cos\theta}{\beta\eta p^{2}} is larger than 1 definitely. So condition 3 is the range of MFL convergence acceleration after combining with MGD convergence guarantee 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1.

∎

VII Simulation and discussion

In this section, we build and evaluate MFL system based on MNIST dataset. We first describe the simulation environment and the relevant sets of parameters. Then, we present and evaluate the comparative simulation results of MFL, FL and MGD under different machine learning models. Finally, the extensive experiments are implemented to explore the impact of γ𝛾\gamma and τ𝜏\tau on MFL convergence performance.

VII-A Simulation Setup

Using the Python, we build a federated network framework where distributed edge nodes coordinate with the central server. In our network, the number of edge nodes can be chosen arbitrarily. SVM, linear regression and logistic regression can be chosen for model training. Their loss functions at node i𝑖i are presented as in Table II [33]. Note that |𝒟i|subscript𝒟𝑖|\mathcal{D}_{i}| is the number of training samples in node i𝑖i and the loss function of logistic regression is cross-entropy. For logistic regression, model output σ​(w,xj)𝜎wsubscriptx𝑗\sigma(\textbf{w},\textbf{x}_{j}) is sigmoid function for non-linear transform. It is defined by

σ​(w,xj)≜11+e−wT​xj.≜𝜎wsubscriptx𝑗11superscript𝑒superscriptwTsubscriptx𝑗\displaystyle\sigma(\textbf{w},\textbf{x}_{j})\triangleq\frac{1}{1+e^{-\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{T}}\textbf{x}_{j}}}. (23)

These three models are trained and tested on MNIST dataset which contains 50,000 training handwritten digits and 10,000 testing handwritten digits. In our experiments, we only utilize 5,000 training samples and 5,000 testing samples because of the limited processing capacities of GD and MGD. In this dataset, the j𝑗j-th sample xjsubscriptx𝑗\textbf{x}_{j} is a 784-dimensional input vector which is vectorized from 28×28282828\times 28 pixel matrix and yjsubscript𝑦𝑗y_{j} is the scalar label corresponding to xjsubscriptx𝑗\textbf{x}_{j}. SVM, linear and logistic regression are used to classify whether the digit is even or odd.

In our experimentation, training and testing samples are randomly allocated to each node, which means the information of each node is uniform. We also simulate FL and centralized MGD as benchmarks. For experimental sets, the system model is set to 4 edge nodes. If the image of xjsubscriptx𝑗\textbf{x}_{j} represents an even number, then we set yj=1subscript𝑦𝑗1y_{j}=1. Otherwise, yj=−1subscript𝑦𝑗1y_{j}=-1. But for logistic regression, we set yj=1subscript𝑦𝑗1y_{j}=1 for the even number and yj=0subscript𝑦𝑗0y_{j}=0 for the odd. The same initializations of model parameters are performed and the same data distributions are set for MFL and FL. Also di​(0)=0subscriptd𝑖00\textbf{d}_{i}(0)=\textbf{0} is set for node i𝑖i. We set the learning step size η=0.002𝜂0.002\eta=0.002 which is sufficiently small, SVM parameter λ=0.3𝜆0.3\lambda=0.3 and the total number of local iterations T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 for the following simulations.

VII-B Simulation Evaluation

In this subsection, we verify the convergence acceleration of MFL and explore the effects of γ𝛾\gamma and τ𝜏\tau on MFL convergence by simulation evaluations.

VII-B1 Convergence

In our first simulation, the models of SVM, linear regression and logistic regression are trained and we verify the convergence of MFL. We set aggregation frequency τ=4𝜏4\tau=4 and momentum attenuation factor γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5. MFL, FL and MGD are performed based on the three machine learning model. MGD is implemented based on the global dataset which is obtained by gathering the distributed data on all nodes. The global loss functions of this three solutions are defined based on the same global training and testing data.

The curves of loss function values and accuracy with iterative times are presented in Fig. 5. We can see that the loss function curves for all the learning models are gradually convergent with iterative times. Similarly, the test accuracy curves for SVM gradually rise until convergence with iterative times. Therefore, convergence of MFL is verified. We also see that the descent speeds of MFL loss function curves on three learning models are always faster than those of FL while the centralized MGD convergence speeds are fastest. So compared with FL, MFL provides a significant improvement on convergence rate. MGD converges with the fastest speed because MFL and FL suffer the delay in global gradient update for τ=4𝜏4\tau=4.

Because linear and logistic regression can not provide the testing accuracy curves, we focus on the SVM model in the following experiments and further explore the impact of MFL parameters on convergence rate.

VII-B2 Effect of γ𝛾\gamma

We evaluate the impact of γ𝛾\gamma on the convergence rate of loss function. In this simulation, we still set aggregation frequency τ=4𝜏4\tau=4.

The experimental results are shown in Fig. 6. Subfigure (a) and (b) show that how different values of γ𝛾\gamma affect the convergence curves of loss function and testing accuracy, respectively. We can see that if γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0, the loss function and accuracy curves of MFL overlap with the corresponding ones of FL because MFL is equivalent to FL for γ=0𝛾0\gamma=0. When γ𝛾\gamma increases from 0 to 0.9, we can see the convergence rates on both loss function curves and accuracy curves also gradually increase. Subfigure (c) shows the change of final loss function value (T=1000𝑇1000T=1000) with 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1. From this subfigure, we can find the final loss function values of MFL are always smaller than FL with 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1. Compared with FL, convergence performance of MFL is improved. This is because 2​(1−β​η)​cos⁡θβ​η​p2>121𝛽𝜂𝜃𝛽𝜂superscript𝑝21\frac{2(1-\beta\eta)\cos\theta}{\beta\eta p^{2}}>1 and according to Proposition 3, the accelerated convergence range of MFL is 0<γ<10𝛾10<\gamma<1. We can see that when 0<γ<0.950𝛾0.950<\gamma<0.95, the loss function values decrease monotonically with γ𝛾\gamma so the convergence rate of MFL increases with γ𝛾\gamma. While γ>0.95𝛾0.95\gamma>0.95, the loss function values of MFL start to increase with a gradual deterioration of MFL convergence performance, and in this situation, MFL can not remain convergence. If the γ𝛾\gamma values are chosen to be close to 1, best around 0.9, MFL reaches the optimal convergence rate.

VII-B3 Effect of τ𝜏\tau

Finally, we evaluate the effect of different τ𝜏\tau on loss function of MFL. We record the final loss function values with τ𝜏\tau based on the three cases of T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 for FL, T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 for MFL and T=60,000𝑇60000T=60,000 for MFL. We set γ=0.5𝛾0.5\gamma=0.5 for MFL. The curves for the three cases are presented in Fig. 7. Comparing FL with MFL for T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000, we see that the final loss function values of MFL are smaller than those of FL for any τ𝜏\tau. As declared in Proposition 3, under a small magnitude of T𝑇T and η=0.002𝜂0.002\eta=0.002 which is close to 0, MFL always converges much faster than FL. Further, for T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000, the effect of τ𝜏\tau on convergence is slight because the curves of FL and MFL are relatively plain. This can be explained by Lemma 3, where 12​η​φ​T12𝜂𝜑𝑇\frac{1}{2\eta\varphi T} and 12​ω​α​T12𝜔𝛼𝑇\frac{1}{2\omega\alpha T} dominate the convergence upper-bound when the magnitude of T𝑇T is small. While T=60,000𝑇60000T=60,000, change of τ𝜏\tau affects convergence significantly and the final loss function values gradually increase with τ𝜏\tau. As the cases of T=1,000𝑇1000T=1,000 for MFL and FL, the case of T=60,000𝑇60000T=60,000 for MFL has a slight effect on convergence if τ<100𝜏100\tau<100. But if τ>100𝜏100\tau>100, MFL convergence performance is getting worse with τ𝜏\tau. According to the above analysis of τ𝜏\tau, setting an appropriate aggregation frequency will reduce convergence performance slightly with a decline of communication cost (in our cases, τ=100𝜏100\tau=100).

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we have proposed MFL which performs MGD in local update step to solve the distributed machine learning problem. Firstly, we have established global convergence properties of MFL and derived an upper bound on MFL convergence rate. This theoretical upper bound shows that the sequence generated by MFL linearly converges to the global optimum point under certain conditions. Then, compared with FL, MFL provides accelerated convergence performance under the given conditions as presented in Proposition 3. Finally, based on MNIST dataset, our simulation results have verified the MFL convergence and confirmed the accelerated convergence of MFL.

Appendix A MFL vs. Centralized MGD

Proposition 4.

When τ=1𝜏1\tau=1, MFL is equivalent to centralized MGD, i.e., the update rules of MFL yield the following equations:

finally. ∎

Appendix C Proof of increasing of h​(x)ℎ𝑥h(x)

Firstly, we introduce the following lemma.

Lemma 6.

Given A𝐴A, B𝐵B, C𝐶C and D𝐷D according to their definitions, then the following inequality

C​(γ​A)i+D​(γ​B)i≥(1+η​β)i𝐶superscript𝛾𝐴𝑖𝐷superscript𝛾𝐵𝑖superscript1𝜂𝛽𝑖C(\gamma A)^{i}+D(\gamma B)^{i}\geq(1+\eta\beta)^{i}

holds for i=0,1,2,3,…𝑖0123…i=0,1,2,3,....

Proof.

Note that C+D=1𝐶𝐷1C+D=1 and C>0,D>0formulae-sequence𝐶0𝐷0C>0,D>0. When i=0𝑖0i=0, C​(γ​A)i+D​(γ​B)i=(1+η​β)i=0𝐶superscript𝛾𝐴𝑖𝐷superscript𝛾𝐵𝑖superscript1𝜂𝛽𝑖0C(\gamma A)^{i}+D(\gamma B)^{i}=(1+\eta\beta)^{i}=0 and the inequality holds. When i=1𝑖1i=1,

C​(γ​A)i+D​(γ​B)i𝐶superscript𝛾𝐴𝑖𝐷superscript𝛾𝐵𝑖\displaystyle C(\gamma A)^{i}+D(\gamma B)^{i}
=\displaystyle= γ​(C​A+D​B)𝛾𝐶𝐴𝐷𝐵\displaystyle\gamma(CA+DB)
=\displaystyle= γ​(A−1A−B​A+1−BA−B​B)𝛾𝐴1𝐴𝐵𝐴1𝐵𝐴𝐵𝐵\displaystyle\gamma\left(\frac{A-1}{A-B}A+\frac{1-B}{A-B}B\right)
(from the definition of C,D𝐶𝐷C,D)
=\displaystyle= γ​(A+B−1)𝛾𝐴𝐵1\displaystyle\gamma(A+B-1)
(from A+B=1+γ+η​βγ𝐴𝐵1𝛾𝜂𝛽𝛾A+B=\frac{1+\gamma+\eta\beta}{\gamma})
=\displaystyle= 1+η​β.1𝜂𝛽\displaystyle 1+\eta\beta.

The equality still holds. When i>1𝑖1i>1(i𝑖i is an integer), according to Jensen’s inequality, we have

C​(γ​A)i+D​(γ​B)i𝐶superscript𝛾𝐴𝑖𝐷superscript𝛾𝐵𝑖\displaystyle C(\gamma A)^{i}+D(\gamma B)^{i}
>\displaystyle> (γ​C​A+γ​D​B)isuperscript𝛾𝐶𝐴𝛾𝐷𝐵𝑖\displaystyle(\gamma CA+\gamma DB)^{i}
(because f​(x)=xi𝑓𝑥superscript𝑥𝑖f(x)=x^{i} is concave)
=\displaystyle= (1+η​β)i.superscript1𝜂𝛽𝑖\displaystyle(1+\eta\beta)^{i}.
(from i=1𝑖1i=1)

In summary, we have proven the above lemma. ∎

Appendix E Proof of Proposition 2

Proof.

Given cos⁡θ≥0𝜃0\cos\theta\geq 0, 0<η​β<10𝜂𝛽10<\eta\beta<1 and 0≤γ<10𝛾10\leq\gamma<1, condition 111 in Lemma 2 always holds.

Considering ρ​h​(τ)=0𝜌ℎ𝜏0\rho h(\tau)\!=\!0, because α>0𝛼0\alpha>0, condition 444 in Lemma 2 is satisfied. By choosing an arbitrarily small ε𝜀\varepsilon, conditions 222 and 333 in Lemma 2 can be satisfied. Thus, according to the definition of wfsuperscriptwf\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}} and Lemma 2, we have

F​(wf)−F​(w∗)≤F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)≤1T​ω​α.𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptw𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptw1𝑇𝜔𝛼F(\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq F(\textbf{w}(T))-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\frac{1}{T\omega\alpha}.

So we prove Proposition 2 when ρ​h​(τ)=0𝜌ℎ𝜏0\rho h(\tau)=0.

Considering ρ​h​(τ)>0𝜌ℎ𝜏0\rho h(\tau)>0, we set

ε0=1T​(ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε02).subscript𝜀01𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜀02\displaystyle\varepsilon_{0}=\frac{1}{T\left(\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}\right)}. (58)

After solving the above equation, we get

ε0=12​T​ω​α+14​T2​ω2​α2+ρ​h​(τ)ω​α​τsubscript𝜀012𝑇𝜔𝛼14superscript𝑇2superscript𝜔2superscript𝛼2𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜔𝛼𝜏\displaystyle\varepsilon_{0}=\frac{1}{2T\omega\alpha}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{4T^{2}\omega^{2}\alpha^{2}}+\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\omega\alpha\tau}} (59)

where because ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, we remove the negative solution and ε0>0subscript𝜀00\varepsilon_{0}>0. For any ε>ε0𝜀subscript𝜀0\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{0}, it holds that

ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε2≥ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε02.𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscript𝜀2𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜀02\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon^{2}}\geq\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}.

Because ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε02=1ε0​T>0𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜀021subscript𝜀0𝑇0\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}=\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}T}>0 from (58) and (59), condition 444 in Lemma 2 is satisfied. Assume that ∃ε>ε0𝜀subscript𝜀0\exists\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{0} satisfies condition 222 and 333 in Lemma 2, then all conditions have been satisfied. So we have

F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)≤1T​(ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε2)≤1T​(ω​α−ρ​h​(τ)τ​ε02)=ε0.𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptw1𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscript𝜀21𝑇𝜔𝛼𝜌ℎ𝜏𝜏superscriptsubscript𝜀02subscript𝜀0F(\textbf{w}(T))-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\!\leq\!\frac{1}{T\left(\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon^{2}}\right)}\!\leq\!\frac{1}{T\left(\omega\alpha-\frac{\rho h(\tau)}{\tau\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}\right)}\!=\!\varepsilon_{0}.

We derive F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)<ε𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptw𝜀F(\textbf{w}(T))-F(\textbf{w}^{*})<\varepsilon, that contradicts with condition 333 in Lemma 2. Hence, we know that condition 222 and 333 can not be satisfied at the same time for ε>ε0𝜀subscript𝜀0\varepsilon>\varepsilon_{0}. That means either ∃k𝑘\exists k so that F​(w[k]​(k​τ))−F​(w∗)≤ε0𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘𝜏𝐹superscriptwsubscript𝜀0F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(k\tau))-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{0} or F​(w​(T))−F​(w∗)≤ε0𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptwsubscript𝜀0F(\textbf{w}(T))-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{0}. min⁡{mink⁡F​(w[k]​(k​τ));F​(w​(T))}−F​(w∗)≤ε0.subscript𝑘𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘𝜏𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptwsubscript𝜀0\displaystyle\min\left\{\min_{k}F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(k\tau));F(\textbf{w}(T))\right\}-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{0}. (60)

According to Proposition 1, F​(w[k]​(k​τ))≥F​(w​(k​τ))−ρ​h​(τ)𝐹subscriptwdelimited-[]𝑘𝑘𝜏𝐹w𝑘𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏F(\textbf{w}_{[k]}(k\tau))\geq F(\textbf{w}(k\tau))-\rho h(\tau). So (60) is rewritten as

min⁡{mink⁡F​(w​(k​τ))−ρ​h​(τ);F​(w​(T))}−F​(w∗)≤ε0.subscript𝑘𝐹w𝑘𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐹w𝑇𝐹superscriptwsubscript𝜀0\min\left\{\min_{k}F(\textbf{w}(k\tau))-\rho h(\tau);F(\textbf{w}(T))\right\}-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{0}.

When k=K𝑘𝐾k=K, F​(w​(K​τ))−ρ​h​(τ)=F​(w​(T))−ρ​h​(τ)≤F​(w​(T))𝐹w𝐾𝜏𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐹w𝑇𝜌ℎ𝜏𝐹w𝑇F(\textbf{w}(K\tau))-\rho h(\tau)=F(\textbf{w}(T))-\rho h(\tau)\leq F(\textbf{w}(T)). Combining the definition of wfsuperscriptwf\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}}, we obtain

F​(wf)−F​(w∗)≤ε0+ρ​h​(τ)𝐹superscriptwf𝐹superscriptwsubscript𝜀0𝜌ℎ𝜏F(\textbf{w}^{\mathrm{f}})-F(\textbf{w}^{*})\leq\varepsilon_{0}+\rho h(\tau)

that is the result in Proposition 2. ∎

Appendix F

Lemma 7.

limτ→0h​(τ)=0subscript→𝜏0ℎ𝜏0\lim_{\tau\to 0}h(\tau)=0.

Proof.

If τ→0→𝜏0\tau\to 0, we can get limτ→0A=1rsubscript→𝜏0𝐴1𝑟\lim_{\tau\to 0}A=\frac{1}{r}, limτ→0B=1subscript→𝜏0𝐵1\lim_{\tau\to 0}B=1 and limτ→0F=γ(1−γ)2subscript→𝜏0𝐹𝛾superscript1𝛾2\lim_{\tau\to 0}F=\frac{\gamma}{(1-\gamma)^{2}} straightly. Then we have

limτ→0h​(τ)subscript→𝜏0ℎ𝜏\displaystyle\lim_{\tau\to 0}h(\tau)
=\displaystyle= limτ→0η​δ​[E​(γ​A)τ+F​(γ​B)τ−1η​β−γ​(γτ−1)−(γ−1)​τ(γ−1)2]subscript→𝜏0𝜂𝛿delimited-[]𝐸superscript𝛾𝐴𝜏𝐹superscript𝛾𝐵𝜏1𝜂𝛽𝛾superscript𝛾𝜏1𝛾1𝜏superscript𝛾12\displaystyle\lim_{\tau\to 0}\!\eta\delta\left[E(\gamma A)^{\tau}\!+\!F(\gamma B)^{\tau}\!-\!\frac{1}{\eta\beta}\!-\!\frac{\gamma(\gamma^{\tau}-1)-(\gamma-1)\tau}{(\gamma-1)^{2}}\right]

where the last equality is because by using L’Hospital’s rule, we have
